[Robert C. Post] Good afternoon and welcome.
As the Dean, I am often called upon, as has

19.54.text:
been observed many times, to offer introductions,
and that is a duty that our lecturer for today

28.41.text:
once aptly termed the “blessing function.”
And today, it is really my pleasure to bless

36.04.text:
this occasion when Justice Stephen Breyer
comes back to the Yale Law School. And I want

42.63.text:
to especially thank you, Justice Breyer, for
being with us on this difficult occasion,

48.64.text:
with the loss of your longtime colleague Justice
Antonin Scalia. Justice Scalia was, as Justice

55.82.text:
Breyer so eloquently wrote a few days ago
in a tribute to his friend, “a legal titan,”

62.97.text:
who “used his great energy, fine mind, and
stylistic genius to further the rule of law

68.81.text:
as he saw it.” In spirited prose, Justice
Scalia insisted upon the separation of law

77.10.text:
and politics. But, paradoxically, he was actually
a genius at influencing popular attitudes

84.91.text:
toward constitutional law. He was in fact
unmatched in giving jurisprudential voice

90.28.text:
to social movements, and he relished that
role.

94.86.text:
Though Justice Breyer is, alongside of Justice
Scalia, one of the Court’s great scholars

101.05.text:
and intellects, he is not a Justice with whom
one would casually associate the label “popular

109.47.text:
constitutionalism.” Yet, since the 2005
publication of his influential book Active

116.52.text:
Liberty, followed in 2010 by Making Our Democracy
Work, Justice Breyer has engaged in a continuous

125.02.text:
effort to educate the public about the workings
of the Court and the relationship between

130.89.text:
our constitutional law and our democracy.
He has not sought, I should say, to arouse

137.39.text:
a social movement, but instead to sustain
what my predecessor Eugene Rostow might have

143.79.text:
called a “vital national seminar,” albeit
a seminar of an increasingly transnational

150.42.text:
character. Justice Breyer’s new book, The
Court and the World: American Law and the

156.17.text:
New Global Realities, adds yet again to this
invaluable educational project. The book seeks

164.51.text:
to demonstrate both that American law is not,
and should not be, cut off from the global

170.90.text:
legal order. Justice Breyer has crafted this
message to reach a broad audience – from

177.51.text:
classrooms in Tunis to courtrooms in Beijing.
And, of course, he has made special efforts

183.81.text:
to educate the American public, including
a recent appearance on the Late Show with

189.26.text:
Stephen Colbert. Before Justice Breyer came
onstage, there was a raucous musical performance

196.65.text:
by The Dead Weather, and, when everybody’s
ears had stopped ringing, Colbert began the

202.14.text:
interview by offering his own form of blessing.
“Thank you for being here, Justice Breyer,”

207.54.text:
he said, “you’re really classing up the
joint.” So we are especially pleased to

213.54.text:
have Justice Breyer class up this joint on
this topic, because he is a founding member

221.06.text:
of, and an indispensable participant in, our
own Global Constitutionalism Seminar, which

227.65.text:
he has for two decades attended and which
concerns many of the same questions that lie

234.96.text:
at the heart of The Court and the World, his
book. And I say this humbly because I’m

241.04.text:
mindful of the fact that Justice Breyer
has deep ties to our northern neighbor, the

245.81.text:
Harvard Law School, where some believe that
“YALE” is an acronym for “Youth Against

251.18.text:
Law and Education.” Youthful as we are,
here in New Haven, we will never stop searching

258.97.text:
for an occasion to learn from Justice Breyer,
to honor his achievements as a giant of American

265.34.text:
law, and to delight in our special connection
to him.

269.75.text:
Before we hear from our speakers, I’d just like
to say a few words about today’s Symposium

275.30.text:
and the extraordinary man whom it honors.
In September of 1996, Paul Gewirtz, who is

282.94.text:
the founding father of Yale’s own Global
Constitutionalism Seminar, was welcoming Justices

289.10.text:
Breyer and Barak, and others from around the
world to the Seminar’s very first session.

295.07.text:
And at precisely the same time, in the same
month, Frank Michelman was delivering a lecture

301.38.text:
to inaugurate the Brennan Center Jorde Symposium,
which is a Symposium designed to be a living

308.17.text:
memorial to Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
Over each of the past 20 years, the Brennan

315.65.text:
Center Jorde Symposium has provided support
and an occasion for a distinguished lecturer

321.47.text:
to travel to two schools. The fall lecture
is typically held, as it was this last September,

328.47.text:
at Berkeley School of Law, where Professor
Tom Jorde, a graduate of this School, taught

334.14.text:
for many years. Professor Jorde’s intellectual,
legal, and ethical commitments, were, like

340.40.text:
my own, profoundly shaped by the year he spent
as a clerk for Justice William Brennan. And

346.70.text:
today, we thank Tom for his inspired creation
and generous support, as we also thank John

353.18.text:
Kowal, the Brennan Center’s tireless Vice
President for Programs, for keeping this important

363.07.text:
The design of today’s Symposium is an especially
fitting way to remember Justice Brennan. Justice

369.62.text:
Brennan believed deeply that we come to know
ourselves as a free people through impassioned

375.35.text:
debate. Brennan loved to joust, always amicably
and ever cheerfully, but never at the sacrifice

382.91.text:
of his own serious and searching views. Justice
Breyer shares this quality of engagement.

389.84.text:
When asked what he would say to the fiercest
critics of The Court and the World, he replied

395.79.text:
simply, I’m quoting him now, “I say I
have written this book for you.” In this

403.95.text:
spirit of enlightened exchange, today at this
Symposium, two celebrated commentators will

410.52.text:
respond to Justice Breyer’s lecture. The
first, whom the New York Times describes as,

417.15.text:
and I’m quoting now, “John Marshall and
Earl Warren wrapped into one,” served as

422.56.text:
the President of Israel’s Supreme Court
and literally created the Israeli national

428.58.text:
constitution. Because of his deep commitment
to judicial craft, his profound grasp of human

434.92.text:
values, and his inspired internationalism,
Justice Aharon Barak is among the world’s

441.31.text:
most influential jurists. We are also delighted
to welcome Professor Curtis Bradley of Duke

448.76.text:
University Law School, who has generated some
of the most perceptive and, at times, provocative

454.27.text:
scholarship on essentially every aspect of
the dynamic relationship between American

459.99.text:
law and international law. He is a renowned
expert who has set the transnational agenda

466.40.text:
for scholarly debate in the field of foreign
relations law. Today’s Symposium aims to

472.58.text:
draw out the distinctive, and, at times, differing,
voices of these three outstanding figures

479.17.text:
– Breyer, Barak, and Bradley. And its design
expresses the hope that a little Brennan-like

485.24.text: jousting might bring us closer to the truth.

489.55.text:
I would like to close with the thought that
The Court and the World would have delighted

494.76.text:
Justice William Brennan. He shared many of
Justice Breyer’s core philosophical commitments,

500.95.text:
including the radical belief, the radical
belief, that law should make common sense

505.73.text:
and serve democratic values. For Justice Breyer,
the lessons of his father, Irving Breyer,

512.32.text:
a lifelong advocate for San Francisco’s
public schools, are as indelible as the words

517.60.text:
engraved beneath his father’s wristwatch,
which the Justice now wears with pride every

524.19.text:
day. And likewise, Justice Brennan was inspired
by the memory of his own father, a coal heaver

529.84.text:
from County Roscommon, Ireland, who became
Newark’s Commissioner of Public Safety.

535.59.text:
Brennan was inspired by his father to ask
sensible questions of the law – questions

540.71.text:
like: “Why shouldn’t the Constitution’s
demand for fair procedures apply to the needs

546.09.text:
of both rich and poor?” Brennan’s efforts
in Goldberg v. Kelly to answer that very question

552.65.text:
produced, and here I quote Justice Breyer
quoting him: “something rare in the law—

557.91.text:
a symbol of the need for equality, dignity,
and fairness.” As Nat Hentoff observed,

565.40.text:
Justice Brennan was engaged in a “continual
battle for five votes to help the Constitution

571.99.text:
leap off the page and into people’s lives.”
Today, Justice Stephen Breyer carries forward

579.02.text:
that legacy. For, like Brennan, Breyer is
at once boundlessly optimistic about the American

587.81.text:
experiment while deeply humble about the daunting
challenges it faces. Justice Breyer is in

594.48.text:
equal measure a master diplomat and a master
dissenter. His work is at once supple and

601.64.text:
capacious, both well-reasoned and passionate.
Think, for example, of his recent painstakingly

608.50.text:
researched and morally profound call for the
Court to reconsider the constitutionality

614.07.text:
of the death penalty. In an essay written
in the final months of his life, Justice Brennan

619.44.text:
asked of us “continuous hard work” to
protect our truest national treasure, the

626.81.text:
rule of law. And he left us with these words:
“If I have drawn one lesson in my 90 years,

633.70.text:
it is this: To strike another blow for freedom
allows a man to walk a little taller and raise

639.23.text:
his head a little higher. And while he can,
he must.” So, please join me in that spirit

646.82.text:
in offering a warm welcome to Justice Stephen
Breyer. So, before we start, two quick announcements:

666.76.text:
the first is there will be questions after
the panel, and the second is when the time

670.91.text:
comes to adjourn, you’re all invited to
join us for a reception in the Alumni Reading

675.70.text:
Room, but please wait for the Justice and
the panelist to leave the table and leave

680.58.text: the auditorium before you exit. Thank you.

this book. And obviously, he said, I try to

That’s before Breyer wrote this book,”

written this book not really to reply to Justice

It’s serving a different purpose. I mean,

945.57.text:
two. For a general audience, let me put it

Charterhouse of Parma. It’s a great novel,

with Fabrice del Dongo, who’s the hero,

the bullets are flying and the smoke is everywhere,

his horse. And he thinks to himself, “Something
really important is happening here. I wish

979.66.text:
I knew what it was.” And that’s how I
feel when I hear words like interdependence,

986.85.text:
globalization, the world is shorter, I mean

is that you hear. And I thought I would write

1003.13.text:
those words, that interdependence, globalization,

a cliché. But what does it mean concretely

American institution, that’s the Supreme

serve, so I see it. I know it. I know it on

change. And the change that I think, one of

1035.81.text:

our own shores in order to make a sensible

doing. I’m giving, in a sense, a report

about what I see happening, happening not

of law or anything like that. It’s something

world. And in the next few minutes, I’ll

[Curtis Bradley] Even though this is, obviously,

3825.98.text:
Supreme Court than we had expected or anticipated,
I’m absolutely delighted to talk with you

3836.50.text:
book for the reasons you’ve heard. It’s
a very engaging book. You can see how engaging

3840.92.text:
the Justice is himself in person. The book

3846.38.text:
that Justice Breyer mentions in his book,

3850.03.text:
it repeatedly, is that he reminds us that
the Supreme Court is not the world court.

3854.64.text:
He says that several times. And against that
backdrop, he suggests various functions the

3860.38.text:
Supreme Court can perform when it is not the
world court but it faces an increasingly international

3867.32.text:
docket over the sort that he described. He
talks about how it can promote harmonization,

3872.31.text:
foster collaboration, even help to promote
the rule of law.

3876.81.text:
And in this talk I want to emphasize a different
role that I believe the court does perform

3882.40.text:
and I will argue should perform and using
some of the cases that Justice Breyer talks

3886.67.text:
about in his book but not ones he emphasized
today. And I will mention Justice Scalia at

3892.20.text:
one point near the end of my remarks. The
role that I have in mind is a role that the

3898.18.text:
Supreme Court plays in serving as a filter
between international law as it continues

3903.62.text:
to develop and the American constitutional
system. And I will begin by noting that this

3910.15.text:
role is justified because international law
is made through processes that often make

3915.96.text:
it ill-suited, it turns out, for direct application
in the U.S. legal system and also is often

3921.58.text:
designed to perform functions quite different
from those demanded of domestic law. At least

3928.07.text:
those of you in the room who’ve studied
international law know there are two basic

3931.28.text:
bodies of international law— treaties, which
many of us are familiar with, and customary

3936.50.text:
international law, which people are often
less familiar with. The customary law arises

3941.73.text:
out of the evolving practices and beliefs
of nations. And the United States certainly

3946.30.text:
contributes to it, sometimes very substantially,
but it does not require any specific approval

3950.62.text:
process in the United States legal system.
In addition, because it’s unwritten, its

3956.30.text:
content and even the sources that make it
up are often contested and uncertain. Treaties,

3964.11.text:
again more familiar, certainly do engage with
the U.S. legal system. They require, in particular,

3969.57.text:
the agreement of the President of the United
States and 2/3 of the Senate. Nevertheless,

3974.56.text:
because they are often negotiated with representatives
from different legal systems, different legal

3980.02.text:
cultures, they have often wording and terminology
that are distinct from ones that would be

3986.14.text:
typical in the U.S. legal system. Often, the
art of compromise and agreements require resorting

3993.16.text:
to terms that are vague, unspecified, left
for further resolution. In addition, the executive

4003.16.text:
branch plays a particularly predominant role
in the making of treaties much more so than

4007.99.text:
in the legislative process and indeed has
been the U.S. practice since almost the very

4012.19.text:
beginning after George Washington decided
that consulting with the Senate was not really

4016.51.text:
worth the candle, that the Presidents negotiate
treaties by and large without the Senate or

4021.19.text:
the Congress and then present them to that
body for approval after the fact. And here,

4026.33.text:
by the way, I’m only talking about treaties
that go to the Senate. Many agreements raise

4031.17.text:
other issues and are called executive agreements
but are beyond what I will talk about.

4035.11.text:
A third type of international law and a more
modern sort is the output of international

4041.63.text:
institutions themselves, either because they
have the power to engage in their own adjudication

4046.71.text:
of disputes or they have the power to issue,

4052.51.text:
Breyer did mention some of that in his remarks,

4057.51.text:
them often without having to go back to countries
for additional approval. The growth of this

4063.53.text:
international regulatory law in some ways
resembles historically the rise of the administrative

4068.66.text:
state in the United States but without the
same level of domestic oversight. There is

4073.49.text:
no administrative procedure act for international
regulation. And even more than with the treaties,

4080.14.text:
international institutional regulations are
dominated to the extent the U.S. is involved

4084.81.text:
at all, they’re dominated by the executive
branch. The only agents in international organizations

4090.03.text:
on behalf of the United States are agents
of the executive. So, let me use a few of

4094.73.text:
the examples from Justice Breyer’s book
that he didn’t mention to illustrate how

4098.42.text:
the court is aware of these issues and indeed
certainly allows international law to come

4103.81.text:
into the U.S. legal system but also polices
that boundary in order to protect American

4108.91.text:
constitutional values. So, three scenarios
in particular: the relationship between treaties

4114.92.text:
and the unique American federal system of
government; second, the issues, and Justice

4120.42.text:
Breyer adverted to them, posed by delegating
authority away from domestic institutions

4125.39.text:
to international bodies; and finally, the

4132.06.text:
customary norms of international law, a particularly
hot button issue when it comes to human rights

4138.17.text:
So, the first scenario, treaties and the federalism,

4144.69.text:
this Court decided recently was the Bond vs.

4149.90.text:
about it in his book. The United States agreed
to the Chemical Weapons Convention, a very

4154.35.text:
important treaty in 1997, and one of the things
the treaty calls for is to criminalize breaches

4160.45.text:
of its provisions. And Congress did that the
same year. It unfortunately, essentially,

4166.89.text:
photocopied that Chemical Weapons Convention
into the U.S. Code and that convention deliberately

4172.86.text:
has extremely broad language about what a

4177.81.text:
might constitute. Indeed, quoting "Chemical weapons,"

4183.83.text:
any chemical which through its chemical action

4189.52.text:
incapacitation, or permanent harm to humans
or animals." There was a lively oral argument,

4193.96.text:
some of you may recall, in the Supreme Court
about things like giving chocolate to dogs,

4199.16.text:
potatoes to horses, and other things because
it includes anything that could have a chemical

4203.62.text:
reaction that would harm even animals, a very

4210.20.text:
the act could be applied to a woman in Pennsylvania
who stole chemicals from her employer and

4216.48.text:
tried to use them to harm another resident
in Pennsylvania as part of a domestic dispute.

4221.72.text:
Did she violate the Chemical Weapons Convention
Implementation Act? Much churned on it as

4226.52.text:
a matter of civil liberty because the other
crimes that the government might go against

4231.47.text:
her for had relatively low penalties. However,
the statute for the Chemical Weapons Convention

4236.70.text:
offers the maximum penalty of life imprisonment
and that is what the federal prosecutor threatened.

4241.82.text:
She was induced to plea bargain but she did

4247.11.text:
the statute, the Court acknowledged that a

4251.21.text:
that she violated it. She used a chemical
in a way that could’ve caused harm to another

4255.11.text:
human being without a peaceful purpose, that’s
the one exception in the statute, but the

4259.99.text:
Court majority said this in fact would be
inconsistent with the American federal system

4264.27.text:
of government, which has the vast majority
of its criminal law and enforcement at the

4268.48.text:
state and local levels, not at the federal
level, and that includes normally local poisoning

4274.27.text:
cases of this sort. So the Court said that
if Congress really wanted to do this, it needed

4280.67.text:
to have a much clearer statement of its intent
to take over such normally local and state

4286.14.text:
matters of federal criminalization, and it
didn’t believe Congress intended to do this

4291.70.text: in the statute that it enacted. That was federalism.

4296.88.text:
Second type of scenario and a more complicated
case although a very interesting one involving

4302.11.text:
delegations of authority to international
institutions. This case seems like an imaginative

4308.00.text:
law professor’s hypothetical. It had so
many moving parts. It’s going to make your

4311.19.text:
head spin. I will not mention all of these
parts but it’s a terrific and interesting

4314.58.text:
case, and Breyer, Justice Breyer talks about
it in the book, Medellin against Texas. I

4322.37.text:
paused just because there’s so much to say.
It begins with the United Nation’s Charter,

4327.29.text:
perhaps the most important treaty in the world.
All nations are parties to it. The United

4331.65.text:
States, of course, is a party since 1945 when
we set up the UN. It has many provisions.

4336.72.text:
One in this case of particular interest, we
have promised in Article 94 that in any case

4341.50.text:
to which we’re a party, we will abide by
the decisions of the International Court of

4346.02.text:
Justice, which is the judicial arm of the
United Nations. All members of the UN have

4351.61.text:
promised to do that including the U.S. Well,
after, as the decades go on since the 1940s,

4358.94.text:
the United States, very internationalist still
by and large during that period, joins many

4363.43.text:
treaties that allow for disputes under the
treaties to be resolved by the International

4368.07.text:
Court of Justice or the ICJ, to give you one,

4373.60.text:
States joined the Vienna convention on consular

4379.75.text:
consulates and their officials and also very
interestingly has kind of an international

4384.07.text:
Miranda clause in the treaty, which I’ll

a while but became known sometime later, it

4394.38.text:
a foreign national of another party country
to give them notice that they can have their

4400.34.text:
consulate notified of the arrest and to communicate

4404.02.text:
warnings do for other purposes. Well, the
United States in the same year, 1969, and

4409.86.text:
almost certainly would not do this today for

4414.02.text:
an optional protocol that said disputes under

4417.98.text:
arise, can also go to this International Court
of Justice.

4422.04.text:
Many years go by. The United States does an

4425.64.text:
obligation of notifying arrested suspects
of their consular rights. Why did that happen?

4430.51.text:
One of the reasons it happened: most of the
state and local police departments had no

4434.12.text:
idea there was such a treaty to begin with.
So the United States did a poor job of advising

4438.63.text:
them and pushing them to carry out this treaty
obligation. And for a variety of reasons,

4443.78.text:
it didn’t seem to get litigated for quite
some time until people particularly focused

4448.56.text:
on the death penalty of the United States

4452.79.text:
at the state level and understandably thought
that invoking these treaty rights might be

4457.48.text:
beneficial to some of their clients on death
row in various states in the United States,

4461.46.text:
and they started litigating it. But they started

4467.03.text:
are all habeas cases and the habeas law, I
won’t go into that, that would take many

4470.62.text:
lectures but is quite restrictive, your ability
to raise claims after you’ve been convicted and

4476.13.text:
even these treaty claims are being rejected
because of the habeas limits. Well, that didn’t

4481.58.text:
end the litigation. I said many moving parts.
A series of countries starts bringing cases

4486.38.text:
against the United States in the ICJ based
upon the violations of consular rights of

4490.88.text:
their citizens. First, Paraguay, it was the
first country, then Germany on behalf of a

4494.68.text:
couple of brothers in Arizona who were both
executed, and then finally Mexico, bringing

4499.65.text:
kind of an international class action suit
against the United States on behalf of over

4503.91.text:
50 Mexican nationals on death row in various
states. And the United States lost all of

4508.40.text:
these cases despite able advocacy by the state
department. And the ICJ finally made clear

4515.11.text:
that the United States had an obligation to
reopen at least the 51 cases involving these

4520.42.text:
Mexican citizens named in the case called

4526.98.text:
review and reconsideration of their cases
in light of the treaty violations. And then

4533.15.text:
we had one of these Mexican nationals go to
the U.S. Supreme Court arguing they wanted

4537.44.text:
this new hearing that the International Court

4544.06.text:
question, which is, is the obligation of the
United States to abide by the ICJ’s decisions,

4550.28.text:
does that operate itself as domestic law within
the United States legal system or is this

4555.30.text:
something, for example, that Congress might
need to implement or might need some agreement

4558.77.text:
to implement. And it’s particularly important
because Texas law, in this particular case,

4563.71.text:
was otherwise the governing law since the
person was convicted in Texas, on death row

4567.92.text:
in Texas, and Texas law said it’s too late
to bring any legal claims including, by the

4572.80.text:
way, constitutional claims. And therefore,
Texas law would normally say if you haven’t

4577.88.text:
raised your claim at trial or on appeal, you
forfeited it under the rules of procedural

4582.04.text:
default. So, if there’s no domestic law
to override, that Texas law will have the

4586.19.text:
last word. And the Court, and it was divided,
determined that in fact this treaty obligation

4592.98.text:
to the ICJ did not operate as direct immediate
domestic law in the United States and it’s

4598.94.text:
a long story, but the bottom line was that
the majority was not convinced and I, I will

4604.75.text:
say, in my own views for good reason, that
the Senate and the President in 1945 intended

4610.65.text:
when they made the commitment to the ICJ to
allow its decision to have direct effect in

4615.54.text:
criminal proceedings in the United States.
I think, that would have been unfathomable

4618.96.text:
to the Senate and the President in 1945. And
the only enforcement they agreed to in 1945

4623.98.text:
for the ICJ decisions was so the UN Security
Council arm of the UN—as probably most of

4629.28.text:
you know, the United States and a few other
countries is in a unique position in the security

4633.77.text:
council, which is that it has a veto power
deliberately put in in 1945 with United States

4639.59.text:
and some other prevailing parties after World
War II. And the idea that we had a veto over

4644.50.text:
decisions of the Council, the only way to
enforce the ICJ decisions and yet we’re

4648.90.text:
also somehow agreeing to let those decisions
automatically override domestic law and judicial

4653.59.text:
proceedings seems unlikely, and it was unlikely,
said the majority. At any event, the Court

4659.42.text:
was looking to try to figure out what these
treaty obligations should or should not do

4664.40.text:
and whether Congress needed to act. And they
decided that Congress needed to take additional

4668.00.text:
steps. I’m sad to report Congress has not
done so. What a shock.

4673.99.text:
Final example concerns and this is one that
gets into the human rights area which is customary

4680.02.text:
international law, and the case, I’ll mention
one case, the Court has had a couple, the

4685.92.text:
Sosa against Alvarez-Machain cases, all of
these cases, by the way, nicely discussed

4689.40.text:
in Justice Breyer’s book. This case involves
a very old statute called the Alien Tort Statute,

4695.86.text:
which was written first of the statutes in
the United States in 1789, one provision in

4701.48.text:
a big set of statutes that sets up all the
federal court system, buried in one section

4705.73.text:
called Section 9, and it just says in one
sentence that the district courts will have

4709.79.text:
jurisdiction over torts claims by aliens that
are in violation of either the law of nations

4716.21.text:
or treaties. It’s a mysterious statute.
There’s no legislative history. It basically

4721.94.text:
gets buried in the statute books for almost
200 years. There are almost no cases for 190

4727.04.text:
years ever successfully relying on that statute
for jurisdiction until a second circuit court

4733.08.text:
of appeals in a human rights case called Filartiga
